name: lyonia-lucida
country-or-region-of-origin: SE North America, NC and Cuba
wildlife-value: It provides excellent cover, especially in the winter.  Its flowers are attractive to bees, butterflies and other pollinators. Members of the genus Lyonia support the following specialized bees: Colletes product and Melitta (Cilissa) melittoides.
light: Dappled Sunlight (Shade through upper canopy all day)
Deep shade (Less than 2 hours to no direct sunlight)
Partial Shade (Direct sunlight only part of the day, 2-6 hours)
fruit-description: 5-parted oval seed capsules. Displays from September to October.
flower-description: Pinkish flowers are urn-shaped and bloom in clusters from April to June. Color can also be red or white.
leaf-description: The leaves are smooth, thick, shiny, and evergreen. A major vein encircles each leaf just inside the edge, and a distinct ridge occurs around the lower side of the leaf margin. The midrib is lighter in color. They are 4 inches long and 2 inches wide.
bark-description: Brown bark which splits and finely shreds.
stem-description: Twigs are scaley, brown and angular
poison-symptoms:
Signs of Toxicity occur usually within six hours of consuming the plant.  Symptoms include lack of coordination, excessive salivation, abdominal pain, bloating, nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, headache,  weakness, muscular spasms, watering of eyes and nose, slow pulse, colic, ataxia, depression, sweating,  tingling of skin, convulsions, paralysis, coma, and sometimes even death.
Toxicity in sheep, goats, cattle, and horses is most likely to occur in late winter or early spring when other forage is not available.  Livestock are found down, unable to stand with their head weaving from side to side.
